utterances: Now, that is a good argument, Madeleine, because at the end of 2001, in fact, the United States actually did divert a lot of intelligence assets from the pursuit of al-Qaeda to the war in Iraq, everything from satellite technology to Arabic speakers, various kinds of intelligence assets.
However, just because you recognize that that mistake was made back then doesn't mean you can just undo it now.
First, those intelligence assets are needed in Iraq.
Even if you withdraw troops from Iraq, that's going to be a very messy process, and there aren't a lot of intelligence assets that can be turned from Iraq to al-Qaeda.
And the second thing, Madeleine, is that the Bush administration has already recognized that it needed to refocus on al-Qaeda.
In the last year, there have been dozens of missile strikes from unmanned drones.
They're taking place now every few days in the Pakistan area.
There really is now an intense effort to go after Osama bin Laden and all of al-Qaeda.
So this intense effort happened just in the last year.
Why only in the last year?
Well, before that, they were distracted by Iraq.
But there's another reason why there's been a real ramping up of this effort, and that's that the U.S.
targeting capability has really improved because of advances in the ability to intercept electronic communications, everything from satellite phone calls to emails.
And there is also more cooperation from the government of Pakistan.
So it is easier now.
The United States has a better capability to go after these al-Qaeda assets in that Pakistan region.

Now, Mr. Obama famously said during the campaign that he would go after Osama bin Laden wherever he may be, even if it means going across the border in Pakistan, and, even if it means the government of Pakistan did not grant authority to go over the border, he would do so.
Does that make him even more aggressive than the Bush administration has been with these drone attacks?
That did, in fact, create a bit of a ruckus, both in the primary season with Hillary Clinton and with John McCain.
But it was really more of a dispute over how to talk about the effort than a dispute over what actually to do.
It really was already, as I said, U.S.
policy to go after Osama bin Laden with or without Pakistan's support.
Well, still, Osama bin Laden has not yet been found, despite this aggressive new policy.
Why not?
The answer we get from intelligence experts is simply that he's very good at hiding.

CIA director Michael Hayden spoke about this, Madeleine, last week, just emphasizing that he's in a very rugged and mostly inaccessible area along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border, putting a lot of attention into his own survival.
You know, some people say that he's not that important anymore because he has removed himself from some of the day-to-day aspects of the operations.
But that wasn't Hayden's line.
Here's what he said last week about why it does still make sense to go after him.
Because of his iconic stature, his death or capture clearly would have a significant impact on the confidence of his followers.
This is an organization that has never been through a change at the top.
The truth is, we simply don't know what would happen if bin Laden is killed or captured, but I'm willing to bet that, whatever happens, it would work in our favor.
And, Madeleine, he did say that that is still a top priority of the CIA.
So that returns us to the beginning of this interview and the first question.
Is there anything that President-elect Obama can do differently?
He could perhaps improve international cooperation, which is something that the Bush administration had trouble with.
Secondly, he could really put more of an emphasis on going after the financial underpinnings of the al-Qaeda network.
NPR's intelligence correspondent, Tom Gjelten.
Thanks, Tom.
Thank you, Madeleine.
And there's more coming up on NPR's Day to Day.
This is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Farai Chideya.
Is it all just in your head?
Psychiatrists are still arguing over how much your brain's chemistry affects the way you feel and act.
Serotonin and dopamine are just two of the chemicals that your body generates to regulate your moods.
Drugs and therapy can be used to keep things in balance.
But a lot of African-Americans still steer clear of antidepressants and other medications.
Many of us won't step foot in a psychiatrist's office.
In a few minutes I'll talk with best-selling author Rebecca Walker about her experience on antidepressants, which she took even while she was pregnant.
But first, we'll dive into a discussion on how brain chemistry works and how everything from sunlight to the strength of your local community can affect your mental health.
Dr. Carl Bell is president and CEO of the Community Mental Health Council in Chicago.
He's also a clinical professor of psychiatry and public health at University of Illinois, Chicago.
Dr. Bell, welcome to NEWS & NOTES.
Thank you.
Thank you.
So let's talk basics.
In simple terms, how does our brain chemistry affect our moods?
Well you know, the best example of that would be alcohol in the brain, because that's certainly an issue of brain chemistry.
Alcohol gets in the brain and it creates all kinds of problems.
And because of that, psychiatrists, physicians, have often tried to figure out what's going on that creates mental disorders.
What do you mean by that?
I know, but Margaret, you know what - what do you think I'm going to say?
You think I'm going to call you and say, hey, we're not going to pay you?
All right, you know, hey, we need trust, right?
You know, I'm starving, too.
(Soundbite of music)
These days there's no such thing as a grace period.
I'm getting barked at three days late.
Never used to get that.
No.
And there are people going out of business on them, so they're like, I apologize, but it's - we're nervous.
They're panicked.
Yeah.
Yeah.
The prospect of having to close himself has kept Giarrusso up at night.
His Brookline store is hemorrhaging money, but he hates to even think about shuttering or shrinking the family business his dad built from nothing.
I've got to keep - I've got five brothers and sisters to answer to and my dad.
I've got to keep - someone's got to keep Bowl & Board going.
(Soundbite of table saw)
Another way Giarrusso is trying to gin up business is with custom orders.
(Soundbite of wooden board on table)
One customer wants a butcher-block cart cut smaller.
Another wants lights put into a glass cupboard.
These are all things where we used to just say, no, don't have, you know?
(Soundbite of laughter)
But now, you chase it.
That's all we have to do to survive; I'm all right with it.
As it gets closer to Christmas, however, Giarrusso's jaunty manner starts to wane.
The landlords have just raised his rent 30 percent in Brookline, and he's locked into a four-year lease.
They're charging too much money for what this is.
A cell-phone store can justify these kinds of numbers and a bank, and any of these banks are being bailed out.
It's like, get real.
After agonizing about it for weeks, Giarrusso finally cracks.
Hey.
What's up, Jerry?
How are you?
He comes to ask his realtor Jerry Camplor(ph) to start looking for someone else to take over his lease if the landlords won't give him a break on the rent.
If it gets ugly, then I say, all right, see you later.
I pull out end of December, and you put the big signs up and just really push it.
